Award.AwardTitle: Identification of RNA editing factors in the primitive eukaryote, Physarum

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to identify factors responsible for RNA editing. RNA editing involves specific alterations of RNA molecules, relative to the genes from which they were copied, and affects expression of genes in mitochondria, the organelles responsible for energy generation in the cell. Whereas, RNA editing is widespread in many organisms, including humans, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. This research will fill that knowledge gap and provide new insights how RNA editing occurs. The project will also provide training opportunities at many levels through concerted efforts to involve high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. One such effort will be to continue ongoing work with a high school teacher and students to develop experiments that can be done in an inner city school setting. Specific outreach to women and minority students will help broaden participation in science. Students will take part directly in the research, gaining valuable experience by learning how to optimize methods, master state-of-the-art techniques, and present the results of their work as part of the project's dissemination of the research outcomes to the broader scientific community.

RNA editing occurs in many organisms and has been most extensively studied in humans and other mammals, plants, and human pathogens. Observed sequence changes include base conversions, base substitutions, the deletion of encoded nucleotides, and the insertion of additional residues. The only organism known to carry out all of these forms of editing is the primitive eukaryote Physarum polycephalum. The sequence of virtually all of the mRNAs, rRNAs, and tRNAs encoded in Physarum mitochondria differs from that of the mitochondrial genome in highly specific and reproducible ways. Many RNAs contain so many non-encoded nucleotides that their genes escaped identification for years. Previous work has shown that "extra" nucleotides are added to these RNAs during their synthesis and that the specificity of editing depends on template elements that flank editing sites; however, the underlying mechanism is still mysterious. The major aim of this project is to identify the factors that are required for these site-specific changes to mitochondrial RNAs. Previous work on two different forms of editing has narrowed the list of potential candidates for each type and these will be investigated further. The expression of each of these proteins will be knocked down individually and mitochondrial RNAs will be analyzed to determine whether RNA editing levels are reduced. Once editing factors are identified, their interactions with other mitochondrial proteins will be examined. Long-term goals for the project include the development of an in vitro system assembled from defined components for use in mechanistic studies and the definition of the specific roles played by both template elements and auxiliary factors. Successful completion of these studies will significantly enhance current understanding of how RNA sequence changes can be targeted in an exquisitely specific manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  

Deciphering the genetic information stored in our DNA is much more complex than originally thought, including many deviations from the standard textbook view.  Normally, RNA is an exact copy of the DNA from which it is made.  Certain RNAs, however, are changed in highly specific ways via a process termed RNA editing.  RNA editing is widespread, and has been extensively studied in organisms ranging from viruses and other parasites to mammals.  Changes in RNA editing patterns have been linked to a number of human diseases, including cancers and neurological disorders.  Editing results in sequence alterations that include changing one base to another, deleting encoded nucleotides, or inserting additional residues.  Changes within regions of the RNA that are translated into proteins generally result in the production of altered forms, affecting protein activity, specificity, and/or regulation.  Physarum polycephalum (Pp) is unique in that it carries out all three major forms of editing within a single cell.  Editing is extensive in these primitive organisms and the site-specific changes within its mitochondrial RNAs are necessary to sustain life.  Previous work has shown that ‘extra’ nucleotides are added during RNA synthesis and that the specificity of editing depends on template elements surrounding editing sites; however, the underlying mechanism of this unique process is still mysterious.  To identify the cellular machinery involved in this process, a novel enrichment strategy for editing-competent complexes was devised to reduce the number of potential editing factors to a relatively short list of candidates.  This grant had three major objectives:  i) assessing whether any of these candidates play a role in the insertion of nucleotides not encoded in the DNA, ii) identifying editing factor candidates that directly interact with the transcription machinery, and iii) investigating whether a protein with similarities to plant factors required for a separate form of editing involving C-to-U changes plays an analogous role in Pp mitochondria. 

It was first necessary to develop a reproducible means of reducing the expression of individual genes to very low levels.  Multiple methods were assessed prior to settling on a highly effective but labor-intensive approach involving microinjection of small RNAs into single cells.  Thus far, the expression of approximately two-thirds of the editing factor candidates has been knocked down individually, but no effects on editing have been observed.  The remaining candidates are being targeted in ongoing experiments.  Given the tight coupling of RNA synthesis and editing within the cell, an alternative means of identifying potential editing factors involves determining whether they interact directly with the RNA synthesis machinery.  Two candidates that interact with the enzyme that copies DNA into RNA have been identified; these will be the next knock-down targets.  Finally, the expression of the Pp protein that most closely resembles editing factors in plants has also been knocked down via microinjection, but this had no effect on C-to-U editing in Pp mitochondria.  Other related proteins will be targeted in future experiments.  Long-term goals for the project include the development of a system assembled from defined components for detailed mechanistic studies and the definition of the specific roles played by both template elements and auxiliary factors once they are identified. 

 

Broader Impacts:  

Integration of research and education:  This grant provided training/professional development opportunities for a graduate student, an undergraduate student, 3 community college students, 4 high school students, and 2 high school science teachers.   Five students were from demographic groups underrepresented in the sciences.  Students were exposed to a diverse array of laboratory techniques, acquiring experience in the design, implementation, documentation, and interpretation of experiments.  Students developed presentation skills through participation in lab meetings, symposia, and regional meetings.  Writing proficiency was cultivated through the preparation of a capstone research report, poster abstracts, thesis reports, and project summaries.  The graduate student is now working as a science writer and the undergraduate student is currently pursing a pharmacy degree.  Two of the high school students won awards based on their presentations and are now attending prestigious universities.  The goal of the community college program is to encourage underrepresented minority students to continue their education.  One of these students is now headed to medical school; the other two plan to complete a four-year degree once they graduate.  Participation in an outreach project in the Cleveland Public Schools had previously led to the establishment of a collaboration with local high school science teachers.  Two teachers spent time in the laboratory learning basic molecular biology techniques, training to use donated equipment, and carrying out experiments.  Laboratory exercises developed with these teachers are now being used in multiple high school classes.  The primary goal of this ongoing collaboration, as well as other local outreach activities, is to engage underrepresented minority students in STEM activities to encourage them to consider careers in science.
